remarks.para: Usually used with Sql Azure. Sql Error numbers checked are:

item.description: A network-related or instance-specific error occurred while establishing a connection to SQL Server. The server was not found or was not accessible. Verify that the instance name is correct and that SQL Server is configured to allow remote connections. (provider: TCP Provider, error: 0 - No such host is known.)
The service is currently busy. Retry the request after 10 seconds.
The limit for the database has been reached.
The server is currently too busy to support the minimum guarantee of requests for this database.
A transport-level error has occurred when receiving results from the server. An established connection was aborted by the software in your host machine.
A transport-level error has occurred when sending the request to the server. (provider: TCP Provider, error: 0 - An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.)

A network-related or instance-specific error occurred while establishing a connection to SQL Server. The server was not found or was not accessible. Verify that the instance name is correct and that SQL Server is configured to allow remote connections. (provider: TCP Provider, error: 0 - A connection attempt failed because the connected party did not properly respond after a period of time, or established connection failed because connected host has failed to respond.)"
The service has encountered an error processing your request. Please try again.
The service has encountered an error processing your request. Please try again.
Database is not currently available. Please retry the connection later. If the problem persists, contact customer support, and provide them the session tracing ID.
The service has encountered an error processing your request. Please try again.

The client was unable to establish a connection because of an error during connection initialization process before login. Possible causes include the following: the client tried to connect to an unsupported version of SQL Server; the server was too busy to accept new connections; or there was a resource limitation (insufficient memory or maximum allowed connections) on the server. (provider: TCP Provider, error: 0 - An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.)
A connection was successfully established with the server, but then an error occurred during the login process.
The instance of SQL Server you attempted to connect to does not support encryption.

member.returns: true if the specified is transient; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingMode
member.summary: Defines the possible throttling modes in SQL Database.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingMode.NoThrottling
member.summary: Corresponds to the "No Throttling" throttling mode, in which all SQL statements can be processed.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingMode.RejectUpdateInsert
member.summary: Corresponds to the "Reject Update / Insert" throttling mode, in which SQL statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, CREATE TABLE, and CREATE INDEX are rejected.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingMode.RejectAllWrites
member.summary: Corresponds to the "Reject All Writes" throttling mode, in which SQL statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, CREATE, and DROP are rejected.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingMode.RejectAll
member.summary: Corresponds to the "Reject All" throttling mode, in which all SQL statements are rejected.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingMode.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown throttling mode whereby throttling mode cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: T:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingType
member.summary: Defines the possible throttling types in SQL Database.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingType.None
member.summary: Indicates that no throttling was applied to a given resource.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingType.Soft
member.summary: Corresponds to a soft throttling type. Soft throttling is applied when machine resources such as, CPU, I/O, storage, and worker threads exceed predefined safety thresholds despite the load balancers best efforts.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingType.Hard
member.summary: Corresponds to a hard throttling type. Hard throttling is applied when the machine is out of resources, for example storage space. With hard throttling, no new connections are allowed to the databases hosted on the machine until resources are freed up.

member.name: F:DimensionData.Toolset.Data.TransientStrategies.ThrottlingType.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown throttling type in the event that the throttling type cannot be determined with certainty.
